channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates and Full Analysis
item.description: The president’s remarks come as the administration weighs extending border restrictions. A top W.H.O. official says the virus “may never go away.”

item.title: Coronavirus Canceled County Fairs. Now Children Show Their Cows and Sheep Virtually.
item.description: The coronavirus has thwarted summertime fairs, a tradition for youngsters who work on farms all year for their moment in the ring.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: Emma Helsinger, 9, has entered virtual shows in Ohio but said she was disappointed she did not get to show off her pigs in the ring.

item.title: Autopsy Shows Ahmaud Arbery Was Shot Twice in the Chest
item.description: The autopsy report, which also showed Mr. Arbery had no drugs or alcohol in his system, came as activists renewed their protests against prosecutors’ handling of the investigation into his death.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
item.media:description: Ahmaud Arbery was shot and killed in Brunswick, Ga., in February. “That day is just a day in a long history of atrocities,” State Representative James Beverly said of the episode.

item.title: Coronavirus Will Keep Cal State University Classes Online in the Fall
item.description: The move by the nation’s largest four-year public university system comes as many other schools insist they will find a way to bring students back to campus despite the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Hans Gutknecht/Orange County Register, via ZUMA Wire
item.media:description: The California State University, Northridge, campus in March. The system’s chancellor said on Tuesday that the risk was too great to bring back 480,000 undergraduates to 23 campuses in the fall.

item.title: Mike Garcia Wins California 25 in Special Election
item.description: Mike Garcia, who won the endorsement of President Trump, flipped California’s 25th Congressional District after Representative Katie Hill, a Democrat, resigned last year.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Cynthia Smalley/Mike Garcia For Congress, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mike Garcia won California’s 25th Congressional District.

item.title: Joel Kupperman, Scarred by Success as a ‘Quiz Kid,’ Dies at 83
item.description: As a philosophy professor in adulthood, he would not speak of the World War II-era radio show (later on TV) that had made him famous and left him embittered.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Six-year-old Joel Kupperman as a contestant on the radio show “The Quiz Kids” in 1943. He and other young contestants found nationwide fame answering questions about math, literature, sports and history.

item.title: In a First, Renewable Energy Is Poised to Eclipse Coal in U.S.
item.description: The coronavirus has pushed the coal industry to once-unthinkable lows, and the consequences for climate change are big.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Libby March for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kintigh Generating Station in Somerset, N.Y., the state’s last coal-burning plant, just before it was shut down in March.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Curb ‘Faithless Electors’
item.description: Fearing chaos, several justices said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Delegates looking at an interactive Electoral College map at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in 2016.

item.title: Coronavirus Wrecked Tesla’s Momentum and Elon Musk Is Furious
item.description: Mr. Musk opened his California factory this week in defiance of local orders. He has also criticized the response to the pandemic as “dumb” and “fascist.”
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: The employee parking lot at Tesla’s factory in Fremont, Calif., was full on Tuesday after Elon Musk said the plant would restart in violation of a county order.

item.title: Officials in Arkansas Put Travis McCready Concert in Doubt
item.description: Arkansas officials said they would not approve the planned Friday concert by Travis McCready as the promoters announced a second show in nearby Missouri.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Terry Wyatt/Getty Images For Pilgrimage Music & Cultural Festival
item.media:description: Travis McCready, who was slated to perform in a concert in Arkansas on Friday, three days before the state’s reopening for venues with audiences of fewer than 50 people.

item.title: Low-Tech Way to Help Some Covid Patients: Flip Them Over
item.description: Turning ventilated patients onto their stomachs, called proning, helps them by opening their lungs. Now doctors are testing to see if it can keep others off ventilators altogether.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sara Hanif Mirza checking on a patient who was proned at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.

item.title: Venezuelan Oil Company Sues Miami Ex-Congressman Over $50 Million Deal
item.description: Former Representative David Rivera, a strident anti-communist, was quietly consulting for President Nicolás Maduro’s socialist government. He produced five pages of reports, the lawsuit said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: The American subsidiary of a Venezuelan oil company is suing former Representative David Rivera, Republican of Florida, for breach of contract.

item.title: El Dorado and Butte Counties Meet California Guidelines For Reopening
item.description: Wednesday: As California gradually allows businesses to reopen, officials say there still isn’t enough testing to move more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Brian X. Chen
item.media:description: Kenneth Lew wore a face mask while speaking on the phone at Crustacean restaurant in San Francisco on Tuesday.

item.title: On Politics: Fauci Speaks. Is the Government Listening?
item.description: A dire virus warning, and new wrangling over Trump’s tax returns: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, California, Michael Flynn: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: On Annexation, a Green Light Turns Yellow, Pompeo’s Visit to Israel Signals
item.description: Although the secretary of state took pains to avoid publicly addressing the issue, he seemed to caution Israel’s leadership against moving too quickly to annex occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Kobi Gideon/Israel Government Press Office, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, right, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Wednesday. Neither publicly mentioned Israel’s annexation of occupied territory although analysts suspect it was a main point of the visit.

item.title: Joe Biden Has an Edge on Trump in the Polls. So Why Are Democrats Worried?
item.description: The former vice president has unified the party and is leading in the polls. But some Democrats say he faces familiar challenges, including slow decision-making and flaws in his digital operation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a campaign event in Sumter, S.C., in February.

item.title: What Pandemic Scams Are People Falling For
item.description: Fraudsters see opportunities to target us in these uncertain times. Here are their most popular schemes and how we can protect ourselves.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: Stocks Fall as Powell Warns of Lasting Economic Damage: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin in the State Dining Room at the White House in Washington last week.

item.title: Coronavirus Live: World News Coverage
item.description: Some countries are reinstating controls after backsliding, while others are relaxing restrictions, creating a global patchwork. Some are hoping to salvage the coming tourism season.
item.media:description: Michael Ryan, left, head of the W.H.O.’s health emergencies program, said that the virus may not be an enemy that can be permanently eradicated.

item.title: Former Veterans Affairs Doctor Is Charged With Sexual Abuse of Patients
item.description: The doctor, Jonathan Yates, worked at a hospital in West Virginia. He was accused of causing bodily injury to some veterans and abusive sexual contact while they were incapacitated, according to the federal indictment.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: If convicted, Dr. Jonathan Yates could face a maximum penalty of life in prison.

item.title: Kushner, Law Aside, Doesn’t Rule Out Delaying 2020 Election
item.description: The opinion of a White House staff member has no bearing on when the election is held, but his comment played into the concerns of President Trump’s detractors.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law and a senior White House adviser, this week at the Rose Garden. On Monday, the White House ordered all West Wing employees to wear masks unless they are sitting at their desks.

item.title: Mike Garcia, G.O.P. House Candidate, Is Ahead in California
item.description: Mr. Garcia, a political newcomer, was leading Christy Smith in a special election that reflected the nation’s fiercely partisan climate. Republicans also won a House race in Wisconsin.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Mike Garcia won the election to replace former Rep. Katie Hill.

item.title: Judge Hesitates to Accept Justice Dept. Move to Drop Flynn Charge
item.description: Law enforcement officials’ abrupt decision to end the case drew accusations from former colleagues that they had undermined the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, pleaded guilty twice to lying to investigators.

item.title: Coronavirus Ravaged a Choir. But Isolation Helped Contain It.
item.description: One sick singer attended choir practice, infecting 52 others, two of whom died. A study released by the C.D.C. shows that self-isolation and tracing efforts helped contain the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A graphic released with the study.

item.title: Trump Is Courting Black Voters. His Failures on the Virus Are a Problem.
item.description: The president has only fleetingly addressed the pandemic’s outsize impact on black Americans, and made no apparent effort to aggressively tackle the racial disparities.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
item.media:description: President Trump won just 8 percent of African-American voters in the 2016 election, and his campaign is hoping to improve that number in 2020.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Top U.S. health officials testified before Congress and warned that the country was a long way from containing the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: A Spaniel, a Mute Button and Profound Matters of State
item.description: American democracy in the coronavirus era has gone digital or at least more distant, however fitfully and incompletely, as all three branches of government struggle to adapt to a new reality.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci warned in remote testimony to a Senate committee that reopening the country too quickly would risk a new wave of infections.

item.title: McConnell, With Majority at Risk, Returns to an Old Target: Obama
item.description: Allies of the former president say any attempt to silence him will fail.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, on Capitol Hill on Tuesday. Like Mr. Trump, he has sought to shift responsibility for the pandemic to China and the Obama administration.

item.title: When the Campaigns Have Your Digits
item.description: A text from the Trump campaign usually LOOKS LIKE THIS, while Biden texts often go on and on and ….
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: House Democrats Unveil $3 Trillion Pandemic Relief Proposal
item.description: The proposal was immediately rejected by Senate Republicans, who called it too large and far-reaching.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday unveiled a $3 trillion coronavirus aid package on Capitol Hill.
